com.soa.policy.wspolicy

Interface AssertionMarshaller

  • All Known Subinterfaces:
    SubPolicyAssertionMarshaller
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    JaxbAssertionMarshaller, ReflectionAssertionMarshaller, XmlAssertionMarshaller

    public interface AssertionMarshaller
    An interface for all classes that can marshal an Assertion to a DOM-based XML structure and unmarshal a DOM-based XML structure to an Assertion. Marshaller's are used during the marshaling and unmarshaling of policy.

    To be used, an AssertionMarshaller must first be added to a PolicyMarshaller before the PolicyMarshaller is used for marshaling and unmarshaling of policy.

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      javax.xml.namespace.QName[] getSupportedAssertions()
      Returns an array of QNames, each representing the name of an assertion that this AssertionMarshaller can marshal and unmarshal.
      void marshal(Assertion assertion, org.w3c.dom.Element element)
      Marshals the given assertion to the given element.
      Assertion unmarshal(org.w3c.dom.Element element)
      Unmarshals the given element to a new assertion instance created by this class.
      Assertion unmarshal(org.w3c.dom.Element element, Policy subPolicy)
      Identical semantics as unmarshal(Element), except sub-policy was found as a child (or children, in the case of multiple policy) of the given element.

    • Method Detail

      • getSupportedAssertions

        javax.xml.namespace.QName[] getSupportedAssertions()
        Returns an array of QNames, each representing the name of an assertion that this AssertionMarshaller can marshal and unmarshal. PolicyMarshaller uses this association of names to marshallers when deciding which marshaller to call when it has an assertion that needs to be marshaled or unmarshaled.

      • marshal

        void marshal(Assertion assertion,
             org.w3c.dom.Element element)
      throws GException
        Marshals the given assertion to the given element. The assertion should be of a type that this marshaller can marshal. The element is the already created element of the marshaled assertion, not its parent. In this way, marshaling does not involve creating the assertion but only filling the assertion. Additionally, this class is only expected to marshal domain specific policy aspects. Policy specific aspects, such as assertion name, assertion optional, assertion ignorable, and assertion sub-policy are all handled by the policy framework.

        Note that assertion sub-policy will be handled by the policy framework only if the assertion is of type SubPolicyAssertion.

        Parameters:
        assertion - - the assertion to be marshaled.
        element - - the already created element representing the assertion. The element should be filled by this class with domain specific data.
        Throws:
        GException

      • unmarshal

        Assertion unmarshal(org.w3c.dom.Element element)
             throws GException
        Unmarshals the given element to a new assertion instance created by this class. The element should represent an assertion that this class can unmarshal. This class is only expected to unmarshal domain specific policy aspects. Policy specific aspects, such as assertion name, assertion optional, assertion ignorable, and assertion sub-policy are all handled by the policy framework. Note that any assertion sub-policy is not available to this class during unmarshaling. Sub-policy, if it exists, is only set on the assertion later in the unmarshaling process.

        This method implies that the given element contains no sub-policy, and implementors should not search for sub-policy. If an implementor cannot unmarshal their assertion without sub-policy, they should not implement this method. Instead, throw GException(PolicyErrorCode.SUB_POLICY_REQUIRED)

        Parameters:
        element - representing the assertion to be unmarshaled.
        Returns:
        - A new assertion representing the assertion in the element.
        Throws:
        GException

      • unmarshal

        Assertion unmarshal(org.w3c.dom.Element element,
                    Policy subPolicy)
             throws GException
        Identical semantics as unmarshal(Element), except sub-policy was found as a child (or children, in the case of multiple policy) of the given element. If an implementor cannot unmarshal their assertion with sub-policy (sub-policy does not make sense for a given assertion), they should not implement this method. Instead, throw GException(PolicyErrorCode.SUB_POLICY_NOT_SUPPORTED)
        Parameters:
        element - representing the assertion to be unmarshaled.
        subPolicy - the sub-policy found as a child of the given element.
        Throws:
        GException
